thread.title: Shilique Calhoun: Defense not playing like Spartan dawgs
thread.title_full: Shilique Calhoun: Defense not playing like Spartan dawgs

author: freep.com
title: Shilique Calhoun: Defense not playing like Spartan dawgs
text:
MORE EAST LANSING – “Correctable mistakes” is the two-word term of doom for a defense, but Michigan State has to hope the first word becomes reality soon.
The No. 7 Spartans (6-0, 2-0 Big Ten) made winning plays to get out of Rutgers with a 31-24 win Saturday, including a Demetrius Cooper tackle to save a go-ahead touchdown for the Scarlet Knights, an Arjen Colquhoun pass break-up to do the same, then a Shilique Calhoun sprint into the backfield, chasing quarterback Chris Laviano into the arms of Malik McDowell for the clinching sack.
But MSU’s overall defensive play with a 24-14 lead in the third quarter is the concern as the Spartans look toward Saturday’s game at No. 12 Michigan (5-1, 2-0). On consecutive drives, Rutgers drove 170 yards on 27 plays - a 79-yard touchdown drive and a 91-yard field goal drive - to tie the score and set up MSU’s game-winning march.
“I wouldn't say they were wearing us down,” MSU senior defensive end Shilique Calhoun said after winning in the return to his home state. “I would say that we weren't in our gaps, we weren't playing the way Spartan dawgs usually play. And I think we lost a little bit of our focus. (The touchdown drive) kind of got us uneasy and kind of thinking of other things and trying to do other people's jobs.
“But toward the end, we realized we can only do our job and have trust and faith in our teammates that they'll be doing what they need to do, and of course that's what happened. We came up big at the end. I think Malik McDowell had a sack at the end of the game and it just shows if you trust in your teammates, good things can happen. All you can do is do your job. You can't do someone else's job because that's when the defense breaks down.”
That’s been a frequent discussion for MSU this season, and MSU coach Mark Dantonio identified two coverage busts that hurt the Spartans in those drives, to go with 81 rushing yards.
“We’ve got to correct things that we make mistakes on,” Dantonio said, “but I can’t fault the effort of our players or how hard they play or our toughness. We’re gonna keep playing.”
MSU-Indiana kickoff set : MSU’s Oct. 24 home game against Indiana will kick off at 3:30 p.m., the Big Ten announced Monday. The TV network is to be determined.
DETROIT FREE PRESS
Podcast: Spartan Speak, Michigan edition
